attachments.title: Is Julia a Misuse of Free Software in the Name of Open Source?  | Hacker Noon
attachments.text: For the past few days I have been spectating an interesting conversation in the Julia community. Reading the comments of VIP members of the Julia Community has been my motivation in writing this text. I will start with a summary of Julia's history from Wikipedia:

messages.text: Reading some of those comments, I'm wondering if my perception is highly biased. Are people finding Julia more quirky/unpredictable  than python or having trouble replacing python in production? I can't stand to go back to python, but maybe julia specifically comports with the way I think.

messages.text: As someone having this channel as my only entry point to the broad world of programming related blog posts, I'm always puzzled. I have no idea of their relevance or whether they have audience and not a single clue to how the people sharing them discovered them in the first place. Also I am amazed by how plentiful they are.

messages.text:
I wrote a python script for the first time in a year or so yesterday, and I realized that I don't much like the way of performing a function using the dot-accessor after the variable. Like
```foo = "water melon"
foo.split()[0]```
It just feels a little weird. Totes not a deal breaker or anything.

elements.text: I wrote a python script for the first time in a year or so yesterday, and I realized that I don't much like the way of performing a function using the dot-accessor after the variable. Like

foo = "water melon"
foo.split()[0]
It just feels a little weird. Totes not a deal breaker or anything.

messages.text:
I wanted to know how a particular thing that involved wrapping a C-library was done.
So I was like _‚ÄúI will take a glance at the python library that wraps that C library. See how they do it‚Äù_
But no.
The ‚Äúpython‚Äù wrapper, is itself implemented about 50% in C.
Because of course it is.

messages.text: no, `=` is not a normal operator in Julia, it is special syntax.  You'd need a macro to do that (which I'm sure would kind of defeat the purpose)

elements.text: no,
is not a normal operator in Julia, it is special syntax.  You'd need a macro to do that (which I'm sure would kind of defeat the purpose)

messages.text: (for the record, I share your discomfort with `=` as an assignment operator... it is infinitely better than the horrifying R ascii art `<-` but not as good as `:=`)

messages.text: I wonder if it would be completely insane to allow all binary operators to also be defined as macros?  seems like it would have a ton of really nice uses, but on the other hand it could get horribly confusing if people don't use this power responsibly

elements.text: I wonder if it would be completely insane to allow all binary operators to also be defined as macros?  seems like it would have a ton of really nice uses, but on the other hand it could get horribly confusing if people don't use this power responsibly

messages.text: IIRC `:=` was discussed a lot early on, but they decided against it because it wasn‚Äôt normal in most other languages. I think this was a real mistake personally

messages.text:
So LLVM Fortran has a REPL now:
<https://twitter.com/lfortranorg/status/1367507839535640578>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/lfortranorg|@lfortranorg>: Thanks to <https://twitter.com/DominicPoerio|@DominicPoerio>, LFortran now has a multi-line REPL in a terminal (works on all platforms), and it uses the tokens to determine if the line is complete, so you only have to press Enter and it will automatically start a new line such as in the if statement below: <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Evpci-XUUAA3hbE.jpg>
attachments.text: Thanks to <https://twitter.com/DominicPoerio|@DominicPoerio>, LFortran now has a multi-line REPL in a terminal (works on all platforms), and it uses the tokens to determine if the line is complete, so you only have to press Enter and it will automatically start a new line such as in the if statement below: <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Evpci-XUUAA3hbE.jpg>

messages.text:
Today in far-left ideas:
If the subtyping algorithm of Swift can be recast as a term re-writing problem (vis. <https://forums.swift.org/t/formalizing-swift-generics-as-a-term-rewriting-system/45175>), Can the Julia subtyping algorithm be recast as term rewriting with Symbolics.jl? <@U687RKK0E>

attachments.title: Formalizing Swift generics as a term rewriting system
attachments.text: Formalizing Swift generics as a term rewriting system Previously I wrote about how the full generality of the Swift generic system is undecidable. The basic idea is that "finitely-presented monoids" can be written as a Swift protocol where the "word problem" on the monoid reduces to proving an equivalence between two types. Since the word problem is known to be undecidable, this shows that Swift generics (as currently defined) are undecidable. In that post, we started with a finitely-presented ...
attachments.fallback: Swift Forums: Formalizing Swift generics as a term rewriting system

elements.text:
Today in far-left ideas:
If the subtyping algorithm of Swift can be recast as a term re-writing problem (vis.
), Can the Julia subtyping algorithm be recast as term rewriting with Symbolics.jl?
